questions.question: A 47-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhoea, unintentional weight loss, joint pain, pallor, and generalised weakness. Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy revealed characteristic histopathological findings suggestive of Whipple's disease. Which of the following histopathological features would have led to the diagnosis?

options.A: Foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive granules
options.B: Villous atrophy and blunting of the small intestinal mucosa
options.C: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in the lamina propria
options.D: Presence of caseating granulomas and acid-fast bacilli

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive granules Explanation: Accumulation of macrophages filled with PAS-positive granules in the small intestinal lamina propria is seen in Whipple’s disease. Whipple’s disease: Feature Explanation Pathogen Tropheryma whipplei (actinomycete) Symptoms Diarrhoea (due to impaired lymphatic drainage), weight loss, and arthralgia. Others: arthritis, fever, lymphadenopathy, neurologic, cardiac, or pulmonary involvement Histology Characterised by foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria, which contain periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant granules, representing partially digested bacteria within lysosomes Villous atrophy and blunting of the small intestinal mucosa (Option B) : It is not specific to Whipple's disease. In Whipple's disease, although there can be mucosal changes, the presence of foamy macrophages is more definitive. Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in the lamina propria (Option C) : It is not specific to Whipple's disease. While there might be some lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, it is not the hallmark of Whipple's disease. Presence of caseating granulomas and acid-fast bacilli (Option D) : This finding is characteristic of tuberculosis or other infections caused by mycobacteria, not Whipple's disease. Whipple's disease does not typically present with caseating granulomas or acid-fast bacilli.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhoea, abdominal bloating, and unintended weight loss. She reports discomfort after consuming gluten-containing foods. Laboratory tests show elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) levels, prompting a small intestinal biopsy via upper endoscopy. Which of the following combinations of histopathological features will be seen in this condition? Intraepithelial CD8+ T Lymphocytes Crypt hyperplasia Villous atrophy Decreased mitotic activity Inflammatory cell infiltration in lamina propria
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3, 5 Explanation: The scenario is suggestive of celiac disease. Celiac disease: Definition Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals. Synonym Gluten-sensitive enteropathy Celiac sprue Diagnosis Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum Serum markers Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-most sensitive Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)-most specific Histology Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic abdominal pain and diarrhoea, worsening notably after consuming wheat-based foods. Physical examination reveals signs suggestive of malabsorption. Considering celiac disease as a possible diagnosis, which of the following statements regarding its pathogenesis is NOT correct?

options.A: Gliadin peptides in the lamina propria are deamidated by tissue transglutaminase.
options.B: HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8 significantly influences celiac disease susceptibility.
options.C: Gliadin peptides may induce epithelial cells to express IL-15, activating CD8+ lymphocytes.
options.D: Type 1 diabetes, Sjögren syndrome, and IgA nephropathy are associated with celiac disease.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8 significantly influences celiac disease susceptibility. triggered by consuming foods containing gluten, such as wheat, rye, or barley, particularly in individuals with a genetic predisposition. It is influenced by HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8 Pathogenesis of Celiac disease: Gliadin peptides ↓ Resist degradation by digestive enzymes ↓ IL-15 expression ↓ CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes activated ↓ Epithelial damage ↓ Passage of other gliadin peptides into the lamina propria ↓ Tissue transglutaminase deamidates them ↓ Deamidated gliadin peptides ↓ Interacts with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 ↓ Cytokines ↓ More tissue damage Host factors, particularly HLA proteins like HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, determine susceptibility to celiac disease. (Option B) Genetic variations may link celiac disease to other immune disorders, such as type 1 diabetes, thyroiditis, Sjogren syndrome, and IgA nephropathy. (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 784, 785

questions.question: A 35-year-old female who recently returned from a tropical region presents with persistent diarrhoea, weight loss, fatigue, anaemia, and vitamin deficiencies, along with a small intestine biopsy findings of villous atrophy and chronic mucosal inflammation. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is typically NOT affected in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Colon Explanation: The clinical scenario, with a history of returning from a tropical region and biopsy findings, points towards diagnosing Tropical sprue that does not affect the colon Tropical sprue: Predominantly affects the small intestine( duodenum, jejunum, and ileum). It leads to villous atrophy and impaired nutrient absorption. Symptoms - diarrhea, weight loss, anemia vitamin deficiencies, and fatigue. Part of the small intestine Nutrient absorbed Duodenum Iron Jejunum Folic acid Ileum Vitamin B12 Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 785

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and poor weight gain. A peripheral blood smear revealed a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. Biochemical investigations reveal very low levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) MTTP gene mutation Explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings suggest Abetalipoproteinemia, caused by a mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP), which is required for the transfer of lipids to nascent apolipoprotein B polypeptide in the endoplasmic reticulum. Abetalipoproteinemia: Aetiology Mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP) Presentation Extremely low cholesterol and triglycerides Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Symptoms Presents in infancy with failure to thrive, diarrhoea, and steatorrhea. Peripheral smear Presence of acanthocytes-RBCs with peripheral spikes Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 787

questions.question: A 4-week-old infant presents with severe watery diarrhoea and failure to thrive since birth. Stool studies are negative for pathogens. A small bowel biopsy shows villous atrophy, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies within enterocytes, and reduction of microvilli on the enterocyte surface. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.A: It is characterised by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the colon.
options.B: It is associated with mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes.
options.C: Histological findings include villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia.
options.D: It is commonly caused by rotavirus infection, which leads to persistent diarrhoea.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is associated with mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes. Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests Microvillous Inclusion Disease (MVID). Microvillous Inclusion Disease ( MVID): Definition Autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by severe, intractable watery diarrhoea from early infancy. Aetiology Mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes, which are important for developing and maintaining intestinal microvilli. Histology Villous atrophy without marked crypt hyperplasia, appearing as "thin mucosa". The accumulation of PAS-positive granules within the apical cytoplasm of immature enterocytes in the upper crypt is highly characteristic of MVID." Inclusion Disease" data-author="Conrad E Johanson1 , John A Duncan III1 , Petra M Klinge2 , Thomas Brinker2 , Edward G Stopa1 and Gerald D Silverberg" data-hash="764" data-license="CC BY 2.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ultrastructure_of_choroid_epithelium.jpg" data-tags="January2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/vnI6dw0AFZ0BMiYBKCBh1737005152.jpg" /> Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 786

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents with foul-smelling, greasy diarrhoea, bloating, and abdominal cramps following a hiking trip in a remote area. Stool microscopy reveals cysts containing motile trophozoites. A duodenal biopsy shows luminal organisms, as shown in the image, without tissue invasion. Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Giardia lamblia Explanation: The scenario is of Giardia lamblia infestation Giardia lamblia: Definition Flagellated protozoan parasite Commonly associated with contaminated water sources. Symptoms Foul-smelling-greasy diarrhoea Bloating Abdominal cramps. Biopsy findings Luminal organisms attached to the intestinal epithelium Blunting of the villi and inflammation without tissue invasion. Giardia trophozoites on biopsy are often described as resembling "falling leaves" Incorrect options: A)Cryptosporidium Protozoan parasite Causes watery diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals B) Tropheryma whipplei Causes Whipple's disease Gastrointestinal symptoms, arthralgia, and weight loss Histology: PAS-positive foamy macrophages in the intestinal mucosa C) Entamoeba histolytica Protozoan parasite Cause amoebic dysentery Histology: Invasive trophozoites within the colonic mucosa.

questions.question: Which type of ulcer is characterised by multiple punched-out ulcers with undermined edges and necrotic bases on histopathological examination?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Amoebic ulcer Explanation: On histopathological examination, amoebic ulcers caused by Entamoeba histolytica present as multiple punched-out ulcers with undermined edges and necrotic bases. The ulcers often have surrounding inflammation and contain trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica Type of Ulcer Morphology 1. TB Ulcer Large, deep ulcers with irregular borders Microcopy-caseating granulomas and acid-fast bacilli 2. Typhoid Ulcer Solitary clean-based ulcers Microscopy-necrosis with macrophage and lymphocyte infiltration 3. Amoebic Ulcer Multiple punched-out ulcers with undermined edges and necrotic bases with surrounding inflammation Microscopy- trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica 4. Peptic Ulcer Single or few ulcers with smooth margins and necrotic bases Microscopy-chronic inflammation and granulation tissue. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 767, 791

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with severe diarrhoea and abdominal pain after completing a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics for a respiratory infection. Stool studies detect the presence of Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) toxin. A colonoscopy revealed diffuse yellowish plaques covering the colonic mucosa, as shown in the image. Which inflammatory cell type predominantly infiltrates the lamina propria and surface epithelium in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Neutrophils Explanation: The given clinical condition suggests Pseudomembranous colitis, in which neutrophilic infiltration is seen. Pseudomembranous colitis: Aetiology Triggered by Clostridioides difficile infection or antibiotic-associated colitis or antibiotic-associated diarrhea (The worst offenders are clindamycin, ampicillin, amoxicillin and cephalosporins). It is characterised by the formation of pseudomembranes on the colonic mucosa. Disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. Histology Neutrophils densely infiltrate the lamina propria Occasional fibrin thrombi in capillaries Pseudomembrane - an adherent layer of inflammatory cells and debris, with mucopurulent exudate erupting from damaged crypts(volcano lesions).

questions.question: A 32-year-old man presents with chronic abdominal pain, diarrhoea, weight loss, and occasional blood in the stool. A colonoscopy reveals patchy erythema, oedema, and shallow ulcers with intervening normal mucosa in the terminal ileum and colon. The histopathological findings from the affected area are shown below. What histopathological features are observed in this patient's condition?

options.B: Smooth transition between ulcerated and adjacent normal mucosa
options.C: Absence of metaplastic changes in the epithelium
options.D: Uniform distribution of inflammation throughout the affected areas

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Presence of noncaseating granulomas Explanation: The clinical presentation and biopsy findings showing noncaseating granulomas suggest Crohn’s disease. Noncaseating granulomas are a distinctive feature found in about 35% of Crohn's patients upon histopathological examination. These granulomas represent clusters of immune cells, primarily macrophages. They are typically located in the submucosa but can be present in any layer of the intestinal wall. Even though their absence does not necessarily exclude the diagnosis of Crohn's disease, these granulomas are considered a hallmark of the disease. Crohn’s disease histology: Abrupt transition between ulcerated and adjacent normal mucosa Metaplastic changes(pseudopyloric metaplasia,Paneth cell metaplasia) Microscopic pathology can appear patchy even in areas where gross examination suggests diffuse disease.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss. A colonoscopy reveals findings consistent with Crohn's diseaseWhat histological features would you observe in this patient's biopsy?

options.D: Ulcers can extend beyond the mucosa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Ulcers can extend beyond the mucosa Explanation: Crohn’s disease presents with transmural inflammation, which causes deep ulcers. It is characterised by transmural inflammation and can affect the entire intestinal wall thickness, from the mucosa to the serosa. This can lead to deep ulcers that extend beyond the mucosa into the submucosa and even the deeper layers of the intestinal wall. Biopsy findings Crohn’s disease Ulcerative colitis Histologic Features Transmural inflammation Skip lesions Cobblestoning Fibrosis Strictures Mucosal and superficial submucosal inflammation Crypt distortion Granulomas Present in approximately 35% of cases Not present Inflammation Transmural Limited to mucosa and superficial submucosa Mucosal Atrophy It can occur after years of disease May revert to near normal after prolonged remission Muscularis Propria Frequently involved in severe cases Rarely involves Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 799

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) pathogenesis?

options.A: NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease in Asian populations.
options.B: ATG16L1 mutation promotes ATG16L1 degradation and enhances autophagy.
options.C: Dysbiosis is often established at disease presentation in IBD.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dysbiosis is often established at disease presentation in IBD. Explanation: "Dysbiosis" refers to an imbalance in the gut microbiota characterised by shifts in microbial populations and reduced species diversity. This imbalance is commonly observed at the onset of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Dysbiosis can lead to alterations in the gut environment, including increased inflammation and impaired barrier function, which may contribute to the progression of IBD. NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease in Asian populations (Option A) NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease but not with Crohn's disease in Asian populations. ATG16L1 mutation promotes ATG16L1 degradation and enhances autophagy (Option B) The ATG16L1 mutation limits autophagy rather than enhancing it by promoting ATG16L1 degradation. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pagee 799-800

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease is true? continuous inflammation. commonly associated with Crohn's disease. involve any part of the GI tract. disease.

options.A: Ulcerative colitis is characterised by skip lesions, whereas Crohn’s disease typically presents with
options.B: Cobblestone appearance is a feature seen in ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease but is more
options.C: Ulcerative colitis typically begins in the rectum and extends proximally, whereas Crohn's disease can
options.D: Fistulae, strictures, and abscesses are more commonly seen in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn's

questions.explanation: Crohn's disease can involve any part of the GI tract. Correct Answer: C) Ulcerative colitis typically begins in the rectum and extends proximally, whereas Crohn's disease can involve any part of the GI tract. Explanation: Ulcerative Colitis" data-author="NA" data-hash="5743" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="" height="500" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/G8Q5CecG71Nc2y9sklbs1743482114.png" width="500" /> Features Ulcerative colitis Crohn’s disease Location Limited to colon and rectum Can involve any part of the GI tract Distribution Diffuse lesion Patchy, with skip lesions. Gross appearance Mucosal erythema and granularity Broad-based ulcers with a continuous pattern Pseudopolyps Mucosal atrophy Smooth, continuous inflammation Transmural inflammation Aphthous ulcers Cobblestone appearance Fistulae, strictures, abscesses Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping) Complications Toxic megacolon Colonic dilation Mucosal bridges. Strictures Fistulae. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pagee 798-805

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 5-day history of non-bloody, watery diarrhea. He reports that he recently returned from a hiking trip in a rural area where he drank water from a nearby stream. On examination, he appears dehydrated but is otherwise stable. A stool sample was sent for analysis, which revealed the presence of oocysts. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:A) Cryptosporidium Explanation: Cryptosporidiosis is a significant cause of diarrhea worldwide. Cryptosporidium is known to cause non-bloody, watery diarrhea and is commonly associated with drinking contaminated water, particularly from untreated sources such as streams or lakes . The presence of oocysts in the stool supports this diagnosis Transmission : Primarily transmitted through contaminated drinking water . Oocysts are resistant to chlorine, persisting in treated but unfiltered water. Less commonly spread via foodborne routes. Species : Key species include C. hominis and C. parvum . All species complete their life cycle in a single host with asexual and sexual phases. Pathophysiology: As few as 10 oocysts can cause symptomatic infection. Sporozoites are released in the intestine and attach to the brush border of enterocytes. Induces changes in the enterocyte cytoskeleton, leading to engulfment. Causes sodium malabsorption , chloride secretion , and increased tight junction permeability . Results in non-bloody, watery diarrhea . Histological Findings : Mucosal histology is often minimally altered. Persistent infections in children or heavy infections in immunocompromised patients can lead to: Villous atrophy Crypt hyperplasia Inflammatory infiltrates Cryptosporidium organisms are seen as small blue spheres that appear to lie on top of the brush border but are actually enveloped by a thin layer of host cell cytoplasm. The small round blue organisms at the lumenal border are Cryptosporidium Diagnosis : Based on the detection of oocysts in stool samples . Most organisms are concentrated in the terminal ileum and proximal colon , but can be found throughout the gut and other sites in immunodeficient hosts. Microsporidium (Option B): This is the incorrect option. While Microsporidia can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, they are more commonly associated with immunocompromised patients and do not typically present with oocysts in stool samples. Microsporidia are smaller and often require specialized staining techniques for diagnosis. Giardia lamblia (Option C): Giardia can also cause non-bloody diarrhea and is associated with contaminated water, but the typical presentation may include foul-smelling stools and more pronounced abdominal discomfort. The diagnosis would be based on cysts or trophozoites rather than oocysts. Entamoeba histolytica (Option D): This organism usually causes dysentery with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, which does not fit the clinical presentation in this scenario. The diagnosis would be based on the presence of trophozoites or cysts, not oocysts.
